page.title: 03THE VILLAGE OF LINTON
page.content: {Linton}is a typical Anglian name which means{'Flax Farm'}and for many centuries{Flax}was produced here. The houses are ranged round a{Square {Village Green}with{Captains Beck running along the West side of it.{The {Road Bridge}was built in{1892 replacing 2 Fords.{The Pack Horse {Bridge}was called{'Redmayne'}bridge because it was said to be built by {Mrs. Redmayne}in the{17th century.}At the end of the{Green}is the{'Clapper {Bridge'}built with huge Flag Stones but now the Flags are covered with tar. There is a{Ford}on the left hand side of the{Pack Horse Bridge.}The first written records of{Linton}were in The{Domesday Book of 1087.}Today {Linton}is little changed with most of the dwellings being adaptations of the original ones.
